    Antibody-Mediated Delivery of Chimeric BRD4 Degraders. Part 1: Exploration of Antibody Linker, Payload Loading, and Payload Molecular Properties

    • Peter S. Dragovich*

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    The biological and medicinal impacts of proteolysis-targeting chimeras (PROTACs) and related chimeric molecules that effect intracellular degradation of target proteins via ubiquitin ligase-mediated ubiquitination continue to grow. However, these chimeric entities are relatively large compounds that often possess molecular characteristics, which may compromise oral bioavailability, solubility, and/or in vivo pharmacokinetic properties. We therefore explored the conjugation of such molecules to monoclonal antibodies using technologies originally developed for cytotoxic payloads so as to provide alternate delivery options for these novel agents. In this report, we describe the first phase of our systematic development of antibody–drug conjugates (ADCs) derived from bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4)-targeting chimeric degrader entities. We demonstrate the antigen-dependent delivery of the degrader payloads to PC3-S1 prostate cancer cells along with related impacts on MYC transcription and intracellular BRD4 levels. These experiments culminate with the identification of one degrader conjugate, which exhibits antigen-dependent antiproliferation effects in LNCaP prostate cancer cells.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The bromodomain and extraterminal (BET) family of proteins consists of four members (BRD2, BRD3, BRD4, and BRDT), which function as epigenetic “readers” of acetylated histone lysine residues.(1) In the case of BRD4, such interactions are mediated by the protein’s two bromodomain motifs (BD1 and BD2), and disruption of the BRD4–histone affinity is currently viewed as an attractive strategy for the development of novel anticancer agents.(1,2) One of the earliest reported BRD4/BET inhibitors was tert-butyl (S)-2-(4-(4-chlorophenyl)-2,3,9-trimethyl-6H-thieno[3,2-f][1,2,4]triazolo[4,3-a][1,4]diazepin-6-yl)acetate (JQ1, compound 1, Figure 1), and the compound has been extensively profiled in many biological assessments since its initial disclosure.(3) As a result of these and other research activities, multiple BRD4/BET inhibitors have been advanced to clinical-stage evaluations as possible treatments for various oncology indications.(2) These molecules include (S)-2-(4-(4-chlorophenyl)-2,3,9-trimethyl-6H-thieno[3,2-f][1,2,4]triazolo[4,3-a][1,4]diazepin-6-yl)acetamide (TEN-010, RO6870810, compound 2, Figure 1), which is structurally similar to compound 1. Unfortunately, thrombocytopenia frequently limits the clinical applications of BRD4/BET inhibitors,(4) and this unwanted side effect may be associated with the mechanism-of-action of the compounds.(5) Encouragingly, several next-generation BRD4 inhibitors with improved selectivities relative to first-generation compounds are currently undergoing clinical evaluation, and results from these studies are beginning to emerge.(6)
    Heterobifunctional molecules, which form ternary complexes between various ubiquitin ligases (e.g., Von Hippel–Lindau tumor suppressor (VHL),(7) cereblon (CRBN),(8) X-linked inhibitor of apoptosis protein (XIAP),(9) mouse double minute 2 homolog (MDM2)(10)) and BRD4, were recently shown to potently degrade the BRD4 protein (and sometimes other BET family members) and thereby offer possible therapeutic advantages relative to simple BRD4/BET inhibitors. Such biological enhancements may be due to the ability of these compounds to exhibit broader transcriptional impacts compared to related inhibitors that do not degrade the BRD4 protein.(11) One possible drawback of such chimeric molecules is their relatively large molecular size, which may impart physicochemical characteristics that compromise oral bioavailability, solubility, and/or in vivo pharmacokinetic (PK) properties.(12,13) Accordingly, the chimeric BRD4/BET-targeting molecules described in the literature have typically been delivered to animals via subcutaneous (SC)(7) or intraperitoneal (IP)(8) administration routes, although examples of intravenously (IV) and orally (PO) administered chimeric degrader compounds that target other proteins have recently appeared.(14,15)
    In an attempt to provide additional in vivo delivery options for chimeric BET degraders, we wished to explore conjugation of these entities to antibodies using technologies that were originally developed for cytotoxic payloads.(16) In addition to overcoming potential delivery challenges associated with the BET degraders, we were curious to determine whether the described antibody-conjugates might afford improved outcomes in preclinical assessments of thrombocytopenia risks relative to unconjugated anti-BET agents. In this report, we describe our initial explorations of antibody linkers, drug-loading parameters, and payload molecular properties in an effort to maximize BRD4 degradation activity and thereby drive antiproliferation effects. A subsequent disclosure in this journal issue describes the continuation of these activities and culminates with the identification of BET–degrader conjugates that exhibit potent antiproliferation properties in cells and strong efficacy in mouse xenograft models in vivo.(17) These endeavors leverage our prior experiences with creating antibody-conjugates using ERα-targeting chimeric degrader molecules,(18) and a preliminary account of our BET-related research was recently published.(19) Other researchers have also added to this growing field by disclosing their own independent efforts to create alternate chimeric BRD4-degrader antibody–drug conjugates (ADCs).(20) Although various nomenclatures have been employed in the literature to describe the chimeric degrader molecules (e.g., proteolysis-targeting chimeras (PROTACs), specific and nongenetic inhibitor of apoptosis protein (IAP)-dependent protein erasers (SNIPERs), degronimers), for consistency and simplicity purposes, the terms “chimeric degraders” and “degraders” are used to describe such BRD4-targeting entities throughout the remainder of this work. We also did not typically characterize the ability of the chimeric molecules employed in this research to degrade BET family members in addition to BRD4. Such entities are hereafter referred to as “BRD4 degraders” to simply reflect the extent of our characterization activities as opposed to implying selective BET family degradation properties.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    We began our exploration of BRD4-degrader antibody-conjugates by utilizing the maleimide-containing linker-drug 3a (Figure 2) to attach compound 3(21) (the well-known BRD4-targeting and VHL-dependent chimeric degrader “MZ1” that is structurally related to BRD4 inhibitors 1 and 2) to an antibody that recognizes the six transmembrane epithelial antigen of the prostate 1 (STEAP1) cell surface antigen. The STEAP1 protein is known to be overexpressed in a number of human cancers, with levels in prostate cancers being especially high.(22) Importantly, it also exhibits a relatively low expression in a majority of normal human tissues.(22) Cytotoxic antibody–drug conjugates targeting STEAP1 display a strong in vivo efficacy against patient-derived prostate cancer models in an antigen-dependent manner that generally reflects the expression level of the STEAP1 protein and the corresponding ADC cellular uptake.(23) In addition, inhibition and/or degradation of BRD4 by small interfering RNA (siRNA),(24) small-molecule bromodomain binders,(6a,25) and chimeric degraders(7) is known to potently inhibit the growth of prostate cancer cell lines in vitro and to afford potent in vivo efficacy in related mouse tumor models. Collectively, these data suggest that STEAP1-targeting antibody-conjugates, which incorporate BRD4-degrading chimeric degraders, have good potential to exhibit antiproliferative effects against STEAP1-expressing prostate cancer cell lines and mouse xenograft tumor models.
    As expected, based on the prior disclosures mentioned above, compound 3 was a potent and near-complete BRD4 degrader when tested using a PC3 prostate cancer cell line that was engineered to express elevated levels of the STEAP1 antigen(26) (PC3-S1 cell line–see Figure S1a; PC3-S1 BRD4 DC50 and PC3-S1 BRD4 Sinf values–Table 1 and Figure S2a). Consistent with protein degraders often exhibiting more pronounced cellular phenotypes in comparison to simple inhibitors,(11,27) compound 3 displayed more potent (IC50) and more extensive (max inhibition) suppression of MYC gene transcription relative to the related BRD4 inhibitor 1 when tested in a separate assessment using MV4-11 AML cells (Table 1 and Figure S3; see ref (1) for information regarding the relationship between BRD4 inhibition and suppression of MYC gene transcription). Compound 3 also exhibited a more potent antiproliferation activity relative to 1 when tested against the PC3-S1 cell line (PC3-S1 IC50, Table 1 and Figure S4). As both degrader 3 and compound 1 bound to BRD4 with approximately the same affinity (for BRD4 BD2 IC50 values, see Table 1 and Figure S5; for BRD4 BD1 IC50 values, see Table S1 and Figure S5), the improved cellular outcomes observed for the former molecule presumably resulted from its ability to degrade the BRD4 protein instead of simply inhibiting its function.

    a

    Cell-membrane permeability assessment (larger values predict increased intracellular compound concentrations).

    b

    BRD4 BD2 bromodomain binding affinity; for BD1 binding affinities, see Table S1.

    c

    VHL-binding affinity.

    d

    Surface plasmon resonance (SPR) half-life of the BRD4/VHL/compound ternary complex (sum of half-lives determined using BRD4 BD1 and BD2 bromodomains; see Table S3 for individual values).

    e

    Concentration that suppresses MYC gene transcript 50% in MV4-11 AML cells; time point = 4 h.

    f

    Maximum suppression of MYC gene transcript.

    g

    Concentration that achieves 50% degradation of BRD4; time point = 4 h.

    h

    Maximum reduction of BRD4 protein levels relative to dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO)-treated controls.

    i

    Antiproliferation activity; time point = 6 days.

    j

    Approximately a 2:1 mixture of cis-diastereomers (spacer fragment).

    k

    NA, not applicable.

    l

    ND, not determined.

    m

    See the Supporting Information for a discussion on the error associated with each assay. Full chemical structures are depicted in Table S4.

    In our initial conjugation experiments, the maleimide portion of linker-drug 3a was conjugated to a STEAP1-targeting monoclonal antibody (mAb) that contained two engineered Cys residues at the LC-K149 location to afford an ADC (STEAP1–3a-D2) with a drug–antibody ratio (DAR) of close to 2 (Table 2 and Scheme S1; see the Supporting Information for experimental details and full ADC characterization information).(28) The use of such engineered Cys residues enables the generation of highly homogeneous antibody–drug conjugates and is one of the several site-specific conjugation approaches currently employed by the ADC field.(29) Importantly, the LC-K149 mAb attachment site was known from our previous studies of ADCs employing cytotoxic payloads to provide maleimide-derived conjugates, which exhibited excellent in vivo stability properties and which displayed potent efficacy in mouse xenograft tumor models.(30) Accordingly, we anticipated that conjugation of degrader-containing linker-drugs such as 3a to the LC-K149 attachment site would afford ADCs with similarly favorable in vivo stability properties.
    Table 2. Biological Activities of Chimeric Degrader Conjugates Described in This Workk

    d

    e

    g

    j

    k

    See the Supporting Information for a discussion on the error associated with each assay. Full chemical structures are depicted in Table S4.

    Linker-drug 3a contains a methylene alkoxy carbamate moiety, which enabled creation of a covalent attachment between the secondary alcohol present in 3 and the remainder of the linker entity. Similar functionality and payload attachment strategies were described previously by others to afford ADCs derived from auristatins and topoisomerase inhibitors that displayed strong, antigen-dependent in vivo activity in mouse xenograft models.(31) In addition, the linker portion of 3a incorporates a peptidomimetic fragment that was previously shown to be cleaved intracellularly by cathepsin B to efficiently release a variety of attached payloads.(32) STEAP1 conjugates derived from 3a were envisioned to release degrader 3 inside a targeted cell following antigen binding, internalization, trafficking to the lysosome, and subsequent proteolytic degradation of the antibody and/or linker cleavage (see Scheme S2 for additional details regarding the mechanism by which 3a-conjugates are expected to release compound 3). However, since the methylene alkoxy carbamate linker had not been previously applied to chimeric degrader molecules, we were unsure at the outset of our research how efficiently these processes would take place.
    As shown in Table 2 and Figure S2b, treatment of STEAP1-expressing PC3-S1 prostate cancer cells with the STEAP1–3a-D2 conjugate for 72 h afforded measurable degradation of the BRD4 protein as quantified by an immunofluorescence assay. However, the extent of such an activity (Sinf) plateaued at roughly half of the near-complete BRD4 degradation that was observed for the unconjugated chimeric degrader 3 in a related experiment (Table 1 and Figure S2a). When normalized for the drug–antibody ratio to reflect the loading of 3, the DC50 value observed for the STEAP1–3a-D2 conjugate was considerably weaker than that noted for unconjugated 3 (556 versus 23 nM, Tables 1 and 2; see the Supporting Information for details regarding how this normalization was performed). In addition, a control conjugate derived from 3a that recognized the CLL1 cell surface antigen(33) in lieu of STEAP1 exhibited slightly weaker but similar BRD4 degradation activity in the PC3-S1 cell assessment (CLL1–3a-D2, Table 2 and Figure S2b). Since CLL1 was not expected to be present at high levels on the surface of the PC3-S1 cells (Figure S1b), the collective results were inconsistent with the desired delivery of degrader 3 by the STEAP1–3a-D2 conjugate to the PC3-S1 cells in an antigen-dependent manner (as evidenced by a CLL1/STEAP1 DC50 ratio of <10, Table 2). These outcomes indicated that additional studies were required to improve the biological properties of the STEAP1-targeting conjugates.
    One approach to achieve the desired potency improvements was to increase the number of degrader molecules associated with a given ADC. Such “high-DAR” antibody-conjugates should deliver greater quantities of the attached payloads to the interiors of targeted cells relative to the DAR2 ADCs described above. However, it was well-known that appending large numbers of hydrophobic payloads to the surfaces of antibodies often compromised the physiochemical (e.g., aggregation potential) and/or pharmacokinetic properties of the corresponding biologics.(16,34) Accordingly, various technologies have recently emerged that enable reliable generation of “high-DAR” ADCs that also exhibit acceptable pharmacokinetic performance.(31b,35)
    To further our BRD4-degrader antibody-conjugate efforts via a unique “high-DAR” strategy, we engineered Cys residues into the LC-K149, HC-L174, and HC-Y373 sites of the STEAP1-targeting monoclonal antibody employed in the studies described above.(28) Like the LC-K149 location, the HC-L174 and HC-Y373 sites were known from our previous research to independently afford DAR2 maleimide-derived conjugates with excellent in vivo stability properties.(30) Conjugation of the triple mutant STEAP1 mAb with linker-drug 3a afforded an ADC with a DAR value of almost six (STEAP1–3a-D6). As shown in Table 2 and Figure S2b, treatment of PC3-S1 cells with STEAP1–3a-D6 afforded improved BRD4 degradation effects as compared to the outcomes previously observed with the STEAP1–3a-D2 DAR2 conjugate. These enhancements included a more potent normalized DC50 value for STEAP1–3a-D6 relative to STEAP1–3a-D2 (7.9 versus 556 nM, respectively) as well as a greater extent of BRD4 degradation (Sinf = 70 versus 55%, respectively). Importantly, the BRD4 degradation potency of STEAP1–3a-D6 was clearly separated from that exhibited by the corresponding high-DAR control conjugate (CLL1–3a-D6; Table 2 and Figure S2b), indicating that the higher payload loading was now consistent with antigen-dependent delivery of the chimeric degrader. In addition, and in agreement with our previous studies,(30) a second control DAR6 conjugate related to STEAP1–3a-D6 (HER2–3a-D6; see Figure S1c for evidence of low HER2 expression in PC3-S1 cells) exhibited excellent in vitro stability properties in independent experiments conducted using whole blood from mice, rats, cynomolgus monkeys, and humans (Table S2). These data suggested that conjugates such as STEAP1–3a-D6 were likely to exhibit acceptable in vivo stability properties in the various species since our previous ADC studies established (1) a reasonable in vitro to in vivo correlation, and (2) the antigen recognized by a given conjugate did not significantly impact the whole-blood stability outcomes.(36) As a result of the above findings, we focused our subsequent efforts on DAR6 ADCs derived from the engineered LC-K149, HC-L174, and HC-Y373 triple mutant STEAP1 monoclonal antibody. Thus, unless otherwise indicated, all subsequent conjugates described in this work are “high-DAR” (DAR6) entities. For simplicity and clarity purposes, the “D6” nomenclature will be omitted from the names of these conjugates unless a corresponding DAR2 ADC was also prepared (e.g., the conjugates derived from linker-drug 8a below).
    In spite of the ability of both STEAP1–3a-D2 and STEAP1–3a-D6 to degrade BRD4 inside PC3-S1 cells, neither conjugate exhibited measurable antiproliferation effects when tested against this cancer line in vitro (Table 2). These results contrasted with outcomes observed for unconjugated degrader 3, which afforded moderate PC3-S1 growth inhibition when assessed in vitro (Table 1). One possibility for such disparities was that the degree of BRD4 degradation (Sinf) exhibited by STEAP1–3a-D2 and STEAP1–3a-D6 was not sufficiently complete to drive antiproliferation effects in the PC3-S1 cells. Simple examination of the dose–response curves associated with degrader 3 in both the BRD4 degradation and antiproliferation assessments suggested that an Sinf value of at least 85% (measured after 4 h) was required to impact 6 day cell growth parameters (Figure S6). Accordingly, we continued to explore the BRD4-degrader antibody-conjugates with the dual goals of further increasing BRD4 Sinf values while maintaining potent DC50 activities.
    Linker-drugs 3b–d were then examined as alternate means to attach chimeric degrader 3 to the STEAP1-targeting antibody (Figure 2). The methanethiosulfonate (MTS) moiety contained in these entities efficiently reacts with Cys residues on the surfaces of engineered monoclonal antibodies and thereby connects the linker-drugs to the biologics via new disulfide bonds (Scheme S1).(37) Like the maleimide-derived attachments described above, such disulfide connections formed with engineered LC-K149, HC-L174, and HC-Y373 mAb Cys residues exhibited favorable stability properties in both in vitro and in vivo experiments.(30) Our previous studies demonstrated that related conjugates bearing carbamate-containing disulfide linkers could efficiently release attached cytotoxic payloads following internalization into targeted cells, disulfide reduction, and subsequent linker self-immolation.(38) However, at the time the current research was conducted, we had little experience with the analogous carbonate-containing disulfide linkers depicted in structures 3b–d. Thus, although ADCs constructed from these entities might rapidly release the associated chimeric degrader molecules after cellular internalization in a manner analogous to the legacy carbamate-derived conjugates (Scheme S3), we were concerned that the carbonate moieties present in 3b–d might undergo facile hydrolysis while the related ADCs circulated in vivo. We were therefore curious to learn how BRD4-targeting degrader conjugates containing these carbonate-based disulfide linkers performed in both in vitro potency and stability assessments.(39)
    As shown in Table 2, treatment of PC3-S1 cells with the DAR6 STEAP1–3b, STEAP1–3c, and STEAP1–3d conjugates in independent experiments afforded potent and extensive degradation of the BRD4 protein. In contrast to what was observed for the STEAP1–3a-D2 and STEAP1–3a-D6 conjugates above, relatively minimal separations in DC50 values were noted for the disulfide-containing ADCs when compared to the corresponding control conjugates (CLL1–3b, CLL1–3c, and CLL1–3d; Table 2). Similarly muted antigen-dependent effects were observed in some of our previous in vitro studies employing disulfide-linked ADCs, and the phenomenon was shown in those cases to be caused by partial thiol-mediated extracellular cleavage of the disulfide-based antibody attachments under the assay conditions.(40) We suspected that similar assay-related instability was responsible for the strong activity exhibited by the CLL1–3b, CLL1–3c, and CLL1–3d control conjugates described above (but did not confirm this possibility via experiment). Importantly, however, ADCs derived from all three linker-drugs exhibited encouraging in vitro stability properties toward whole blood from multiple species with the most-hindered analog (CLL1–3d) displaying the most stable outcomes (Table S2). These results suggested that STEAP1 and CLL1 conjugates derived from linker-drugs 3b–d would exhibit favorable stability properties if assessed in vivo.(36) In spite of achieving DC50 and Sinf values that were similar to those observed for unconjugated degrader 3, none of the STEAP1 conjugates containing the disulfide linkers exhibited meaningful antiproliferation effects against the PC3-S1 cell line. The origin of this discrepancy is not known with certainty, but the phenomenon may be related to the different time points employed to measure the BRD4 degradation properties of the conjugated and unconjugated entities (72 versus 4 h, respectively). Given this lack of antiproliferation activity, we continued our efforts in search of more promising BRD4-degrader conjugates.
    Although some precedent exists for linker-drugs containing the methylene alkoxy carbamate and carbonate moieties described above to afford biologically active conjugates, the use of these functional groups to attach payloads to antibodies is relatively limited in the ADC field. As such, the ability of these functionalities to efficiently release the attached payloads following internalization of the BRD4-degrader conjugates into cells was not known with certainty. We therefore wished to explore conjugates that utilized carbamates or amides derived from anilines or primary or secondary amines for such attachment purposes. When combined with protease-cleavable linkers (which often include para-amino-benzyloxy (PAB) moieties, which separate the cleavage site from the attached payload), these attachment functionalities are well-known to enable efficient release of attached cytotoxic molecules from antibody–drug conjugates and thereby afford highly active ADCs.(41) However, as compound 3 does not contain anilines or amines in its chemical structure, we sought to introduce these functional groups into the degrader without negatively impacting the biological potencies of the resulting molecules. Analysis of the known crystal structure of compound 1 bound to BRD4(3) indicated that the para-Cl moiety was oriented toward the solvent and made relatively minimal contact with the protein (Figure 3). Related para-aniline-containing derivatives of compound 1 are known in the patent literature, although their affinities for BRD4 have not been reported.(42) In addition, functionally active chimeric BRD4 degraders have been described in the patent literature in which a poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) spacer was attached to the para-position of compound 1 via displacement of the Cl group.(43) Collectively, this information suggested that replacement of the para-Cl present in 1 with aniline or propargyl amine functionalities could be tolerated in the BRD4-binding pocket, and our own molecular docking studies supported this conclusion (Figure S7a,b).
    Accordingly, we synthesized chimeric degraders 4 and 5, which, respectively, contained the aniline and propargyl amine functional groups as para-Cl replacements but otherwise duplicated the chemical structure of compound 3 (Figure 4). As shown in Table 1, the affinity of 4 for BRD4 was somewhat attenuated relative to that observed for 3. However, a similar assessment of 5 revealed minimal BRD4 potency alterations (Table 1). In addition, the affinity of 5 for the VHL protein was determined by a fluorescence polarization assessment to be within twofold of that exhibited by degrader 3 (Table 1 and Figure S8; consistent with the two compounds containing identical VHL-binding moieties). We also utilized surface plasmon resonance (SPR) methods to examine the ability of both 4 and 5 to, respectively, form ternary complexes with the BRD4 and VHL proteins. Such formation was considered a prerequisite for efficient BRD4 degradation, and similar SPR-based techniques were employed by others to assess related BRD4-degrader complexes.(44) Since 4 and 5 bound to either of the BRD4 BD1 and BD2 bromodomains with reasonably potent affinities (Table S1), we measured the half-lives of the BRD4/VHL ternary complexes formed between the degraders and either of these bromodomains in separate, independent SPR experiments (Figure S9 and Table S3). As we did not know which ternary complex was responsible for the compounds’ intracellular BRD4 degradation activities, we chose to combine (via summation) the separately measured BD1 and BD2 SPR half-lives into a single ternary complex half-life parameter for each degrader compound so examined.
    Both 4 and 5 formed BRD4/VHL ternary complexes that were considerably less stable than the one generated by 3 as evidenced by the significantly shorter combined SPR half-lives observed for complexes generated by the former two compounds (Table 1). As a likely result, much weaker activity was observed for 4 and 5 relative to 3 in cell-based assessments of MYC activity, BRD4 degradation (both DC50 and Sinf values), and antiproliferation effects. It is currently unknown exactly why degraders 4 and 5 afforded less stable BRD4/VHL ternary complexes relative to 3. However, retrospective analysis of the BRD4/3/VHL crystal structure,(45) which was not available when 4 and 5 were originally synthesized, indicated that the polar moieties appended to the BRD4-binding moiety in both 4 and 5 may clash with favorable BRD4–VHL interactions in the complex. In general, a reasonable correlation existed between the half-life determined for a given degrader compound in the BRD4/VHL ternary complex assessment and the corresponding BRD4 degradation activity measured in PC3-S1 cells (Figure 5). However, the extent of these relationships was not fully apparent until the majority of the degrader molecules described in this work were appropriately profiled.
    We also suspected that the weaker cell-based activities of 4 and 5 relative to 3 might be partially due to impaired cell penetration properties related to the introduced polar aniline and amine functional groups. Consistent with this hypothesis, the PC3-S1 antiproliferation properties of chimeric degraders 4 and 5 were considerably weaker than those exhibited by the less-polar reversible inhibitor 1, which bound to BRD4 with a similar affinity (Table 1). Accordingly, we profiled the degraders using an immobilized artificial membrane (IAM) assessment for which higher binding (i.e., larger Log k IAM values) was shown by others to correlate well with an increased intracellular compound concentration.(46) Based on these assessments, compound 4 was predicted to be significantly less cell-permeable relative to degraders 3 and 5 (Table 1). The relatively high cell permeability predicted by IAM for compound 5 was somewhat surprising and may reflect either a conformational organization of the molecule that masks the polarity of the propargyl amine moiety or a preferential affinity of basic amines for the phospholipids, which comprise the IAM columns (see the Supporting Information for additional details). Interestingly, the correlation described above between SPR half-life and BRD4 degradation activity could be slightly improved by taking the predicted cell permeability of the chimeric degraders into account via a simple multiplication function (Figure S10a; cf., Figure 5; caveat: different number of data points in each figure). In addition, performing the same analysis using only SPR data associated with BD2 (the BRD4 bromodomain that consistently afforded the longest half-lives; Table S3) resulted in a somewhat poorer correlation (Figure S10b). This outcome suggested that, at least for some of the tested compounds, binding to both BRD4 bromodomains contributed to the degradation results. As mentioned above, the strengths of the described correlations were not fully known during the early phases of our research activities. In addition, we recognized that poor degrader cell permeability properties might be overcome through the antibody-mediated delivery approach that we were exploring. We therefore continued with our plans to prepare and characterize conjugates derived from 4 and 5 to determine whether antibody-mediated delivery of these degrader molecules would afford favorable cell-based outcomes.
    As depicted in Table 2, a STEAP1-targeting conjugate that incorporated 4 by directly attaching a protease-cleavable linker to the degrader’s aniline moiety (STEAP1–4a, Figure 4) exhibited measurable BRD4 degradation activity that was well-separated from that displayed by the corresponding control ADC (HER2–4a). However, the observed DC50 value for the STEAP1 conjugate was relatively weak, and the maximal extent of BRD4 degradation (Sinf) was significantly curtailed as compared to that observed for unconjugated compound 3. Although some precedent existed for directly attaching protease-cleavable linkers to aniline-containing ADC payloads,(41b) we speculated that these outcomes might be related to inefficient protease-mediated release of degrader 4 due to the close proximity of the 4a cleavage site to the BRD4-binding moiety (cf., Scheme S4). Introduction of a self-immolating para-amino-benzyloxy (PAB) group into peptide-based ADC linkers is an established approach to increase separation between protease-cleavage sites and the attached payloads (cf., Scheme S5).(47) Application of this strategy to linker-drug 4a and the corresponding ADC afforded a new conjugate that exhibited near-complete degradation of the BRD4 protein (STEAP1–4b, Figure 4). However, these effects were only observed at relatively high concentrations, which did not enable meaningful separation from the control conjugate (HER2–4b) up to the maximum concentrations routinely tested in our degradation assessments.
    Encouragingly, a conjugate bearing degrader 5 and the same protease-cleavable linker employed for STEAP1–4a exhibited a much more potent BRD4 DC50 value and a more extensive BRD4 degradation outcome (Sinf) relative to the previously studied ADC (STEAP1–5a, Table 2). These improvements potentially resulted from the propargyl amine moiety present in 5a better distancing the linker’s protease-cleavage site from the chimeric degrader relative to the 4a and 4b linkers (see the additional discussion below for alternate possibilities regarding the observed enhancements). Incorporation of a noncleavable linker into the conjugate design led to STEAP1–5b, which exhibited a BRD4 DC50 potency similar to that displayed by STEAP1–5a and further improved the extent of BRD4 degradation exhibited by the latter ADC (Table 2). In contrast to conjugates bearing cleavable linkers, which are designed to release the native chimeric degraders following intracellular internalization, ADCs such as STEAP1–5b derived from noncleavable linkers were expected to be catabolized in the lysosome into highly polar molecules, which retained a cysteine residue from the antibody in their chemical structures (cf., Scheme S6). Based on studies by others of related catabolites, these polar entities were presumed to exhibit poor cell-membrane-permeability properties but were nevertheless expected to effectively transition from the lysosome to the cytosol via mechanisms that might involve active transport.(48) At this juncture in our studies, we did not know whether such impaired cell membrane permeability would improve the degradation outcomes of BRD4 degrader conjugates, possibly by concentrating the nonpermeable catabolites inside a targeted cell,(49) or hinder such activity by limiting bystander effects in nearby cells that were not targeted by the ADC.(50) We also did not attempt to identify or synthesize the intracellular catabolite(s) produced from STEAP1–5b and thus did not assess the ability of such entities to form long-lived BRD4/VHL ternary complexes. The BRD4 degradation results exhibited by the STEAP1–5a and STEAP1–5b conjugates did not obviously differentiate the cleavable and noncleavable linkers. We therefore continued to incorporate both variants in our BRD4-degrader ADC designs, and a detailed comparison of the two linker classes is presented near the end of this work (Figure 11). In addition, none of the STEAP1-targeting ADCs derived from 4a, 4b, 5a, or 5b exhibited both a potent DC50 value and the desired >85% BRD4 degradation extent (Sinf) mentioned above (Table 2). Based on these outcomes, it was not surprising that all such conjugates failed to demonstrate meaningful antiproliferation activity against the PC3-S1 cell line when tested to relatively high concentrations (Table 2).
    As depicted in Table 1 and Figure 3, introduction of the aniline and amine groups into the BRD4-binding region of compound 3 significantly impaired BRD4/degrader/VHL ternary complex formation in our SPR assessments (compare compounds 4 and 5 to 3). We therefore sought to introduce these linker-attachment moieties into other locations within the compound 3 structure with the goal of retaining favorable ternary complex formation properties. Accordingly, we next examined chimeric degraders in which secondary amine functional groups were incorporated into the VHL-binding portion of the molecules (6 and 7, Figure 6). Such introduction preserved the BRD4-binding region of degrader 3 in its native form but instead risked negatively altering the VHL affinities of the new compounds (and thus the ability to form productive ternary complexes with BRD4). The ortho position of the benzylic fragment present in 3 was selected for the introduction of the new functional groups since (1) examination of known cocrystal structures of VHL in complex with related ligands indicated that this vector protruded away from the protein into the solvent (Figure S11) and (2) related derivatization of this position afforded functional chimeric degraders directed at multiple protein targets.(43,51) As shown in Table 1, a molecule containing an ortho-alkoxy substituent that terminated in an N-Me amine moiety displayed a 2–3-fold loss in VHL affinity relative to degrader 3 (compound 6). A related molecule bearing an ortho-piperidine-alkoxy substituent exhibited VHL affinity that was within twofold that displayed by 3 (compound 7, Table 1). As expected based on their identical BRD4-binding domains, both degraders 6 and 7 exhibited BRD4-binding properties that were indistinguishable from 3 (Table 1). When examined in our SPR-based BRD4/VHL ternary complex assessment, compound 7 displayed a somewhat weaker ternary complex half-life relative to degrader 3 (Table 1; compound 6 was not similarly evaluated). Encouragingly, however, the SPR half-life of degrader 7 was substantially improved relative to the values determined above for compounds 4 and 5, which incorporated the polar linker-attachment groups into the BRD4-binding portions of their chemical structures. As a likely result of this improvement, degrader 7 exhibited more potent and more extensive BRD4 degradation properties relative to 4 and 5 in the PC3-S1 cell-based assessment (Table 1). The greater cell permeability predicted by IAM for 7 as compared to 4 and 5 may also have contributed to these outcomes (Table 1; larger Log k IAM values = increased intracellular compound concentration). However, as discussed for compound 5 above, the IAM results for 7 may be misleading due to the basic amine moiety contained in the molecule’s chemical structure.
    STEAP1-targeting conjugates prepared from either 6 or 7 using protease-cleavable (STEAP1–6a and STEAP1–7a) or noncleavable (STEAP1–6b and STEAP1–7b) linkers were active BRD4 degraders in the PC3-S1 cell-based assessment with DC50 values ranging from 0.25 to 3.8 μg/mL (Table 2). In addition, the extent of BRD4 degradation (Sinf) exhibited by these ADCs was generally strong (>85%) although the effects produced by STEAP1–6b were considerably less impressive. Importantly, the activities observed for all of these STEAP1-targeting conjugates were separated by at least 10-fold from the degradation outcomes displayed by the corresponding CLL1 and/or HER2 control ADCs (Table 2, some examples exhibited considerably greater separations). Although many of the tested conjugates afforded relatively potent and extensive BRD4 degradation activity (especially STEAP1–7b), none were active in PC3-S1 antiproliferation experiments when examined up to fairly high concentrations. Based on these outcomes, we began to suspect that an even greater BRD4 degradation potency and/or extent of protein depletion would be required for the conjugates under study to exhibit antiproliferation effects (see the discussion below for more details). However, we were also encouraged that altering the location of the polar linker-attachment moieties within the chimeric degrader chemical structure could produce new BRD4-degrader conjugates with favorable biological properties. In addition, we were pleased that the CLL1–6b, HER2–7a, and HER2–7b conjugates all displayed favorable stability outcomes when tested in the in vitro whole-blood assessment regardless of which species the blood originated from (Table S2). These results demonstrated the suitability for conjugates derived from linker-drugs 6b, 7a, and 7b to be advanced into subsequent in vivo experiments.
    We next examined incorporating aniline and amino groups into the spacer moiety that connected the BRD4 and VHL-binding fragments in the chimeric degrader molecules. Such a location was expected to have minimal impact on the BRD4 and VHL-binding affinities of the resulting compounds but could still interfere with productive formation of the desired BRD4/degrader/VHL ternary complexes. As shown in Figure 7 and Table 1, inclusion of an aniline or a piperidine moiety in the degrader spacer region afforded compounds (8 and 9) that exhibited BRD4 and VHL-binding properties, which were similar to those displayed by degrader 3. Both 8 and 9 were also capable of forming ternary complexes with BRD4/VHL in the SPR-based assessments. Interestingly, the ternary complex half-life displayed by the former molecule was superior (longer) to that exhibited by 3, while the half-life corresponding to the latter degrader was significantly impaired (shorter; Table 1 and Figures 3 and S10). These differences were likely reflected in subsequent PC3-S1 assessments of BRD4 degradation and antiproliferation in which compound 8 displayed improved activities relative to 9 (Table 1). Chimeric BRD4 degraders that contained various aryl and heteroaryl moieties (but not anilines) in their spacer regions were known in the patent literature, and the potent biological activities noted for many such molecules were consistent with what we observed for compound 8 in the current studies.(42) In addition, the large Log k IAM value measured for degrader 9 suggested high intracellular concentrations of the compound. However, as discussed for degraders 5 and 7 above, this outcome may artifactually reflect the presence of a basic amine moiety in the compound 9 chemical structure.
    As part of this phase of our research, we also explored chimeric degraders in which the spacer element was attached to the para-position of the phenyl moiety present in the BRD4-binding fragment (compound 10, Figure 8; cf., Figure 3). This alternate degrader construction was envisioned to diversify the risks of incorporating the polar aniline linker-attachment group in the spacer region via the formation of alternate BRD4/VHL ternary complexes relative to those associated with compounds 8 and 9. The new design also enabled the carboxamide moiety present in the BRD4-binding portion of the previously examined molecules (to which the spacer was attached) to be replaced with a thiazole isostere in an effort to further diversify the molecules. The described alterations were supported by our previous analysis of published structural and biological data suggesting that active BRD4 binders and chimeric degraders could be created via derivatization of the para-phenyl position (see the discussion surrounding Figure 3 above). An additional literature report demonstrated the feasibility of incorporating heterocycles as carboxamide replacements in related BRD4 inhibitors but did not specifically explore thiazoles in this capacity.(52) Degrader 10 exhibited BRD4 and VHL-binding properties that were similar to those displayed by 3 (Table 1). However, the half-life of 10 in the SPR ternary complex assessment was considerably shorter than that of 3, and as a likely result, the former compound exhibited a somewhat weaker activity relative to the latter in the MYC suppression and PC3-S1 BRD4 degradation and antiproliferation assays (Table 1).
    Compound 10 was nevertheless a relatively active BRD4 degrader, and we therefore utilized its alternate design to explore the effects of introducing a strongly acidic sulfonic acid group into the chimeric molecular structure (compound 11). As shown in Table 1, degrader 11 displayed BRD4-binding properties that were slightly improved relative to 10 and also formed a BRD4/VHL ternary complex with a very similar SPR half-life. However, due to the strong ionization of the sulfonic acid group at physiological pH, the cell penetration properties predicted for 11 by IAM assessment were the poorest of all of the compounds studied in this work (Table 1). Accordingly, compound 11 was not active in the cell-based MYC suppression, PC3-S1 BRD4 degradation, and PC3-S1 antiproliferation assays up to the highest concentration tested. Based on these outcomes, degrader 11 provided us with an opportunity to evaluate the performance of BRD4-degrader-ADCs, which released cell-impermeable payloads that would complement the studies we performed above with conjugates constructed using noncleavable linkers (e.g., those derived from 5b, 6b, 7b, and 9b).
    A DAR2 STEAP1-targeting ADC that incorporated degrader 8 using a protease-cleavable linker failed to show measurable BRD4 degradation activity when assessed in PC3-S1 cells (Table 2, STEAP1–8a-D2). In contrast, a DAR6 STEAP1 conjugate constructed using the same linker-drug moiety was active in the degradation assessment, although the extent of BRD4 depletion was less than our 85% target value (Table 2, STEAP1–8a-D6). This outcome provided a second head-to-head comparison of DAR2 and DAR6 conjugates, and it underscored the importance of the higher payload loading in achieving meaningful BRD4 degradation results (cf., STEAP1–3a-D2 versus STEAP1–3a-D6 in Table 2 and the corresponding discussion above). DAR6 STEAP1 conjugates derived from the piperidine-containing degrader 9 using either a protease-cleavable (STEAP1–9a) or a noncleavable (STEAP1–9b) linker displayed significantly less potent DC50 values relative to STEAP1–8a-D6 but also degraded the BRD4 protein more extensively (Sinf, Table 2). The STEAP-targeting ADCs that incorporated chimeric degraders bearing the alternate BRD4 binder connection design (STEAP1–10a and STEAP1–10b) displayed similarly inferior DC50 values as compared to STEAP1–8a-D6 but with comparable Sinf outcomes (Table 2).
    The weaker biological activity observed for DAR6 conjugates derived from degraders 9 and 10 relative to that prepared from 8 may be due to the impaired ability of the two former molecules to form long-lived ternary complexes with the BRD4 and VHL proteins relative to the latter compound (cf., Table 1). Importantly, the conjugate bearing the cell-impermeable, sulfonic acid-containing degrader molecule and a protease-cleavable linker (STEAP1–11a) was completely inert in the PC3-S1 BRD4 degradation assessments (Table 2). This result, and the relatively favorable anti-BRD4 activity exhibited by STEAP1–8a-D6, which released a structurally related cell-permeable degrader payload via the identical linker, indicated that preserving some measure of cell permeability in the chimeric degrader payload was an important component of creating an active ADC capable of degrading BRD4 (see the additional discussion below related to cleavable versus noncleavable linkers). Consistent with results for the HER2–7a conjugate, the HER2–8a-D6 ADC, which contains a similar protease-cleavable linker, displayed excellent in vitro stability properties when exposed to whole blood from various species for 24 h (Table S2).
    All of the newly constructed chimeric BRD4 degraders explored to this point in this work exhibited weaker cell-based potencies in the MYC suppression, PC3-S1 BRD4 degradation, and PC3-S1 antiproliferation assessments relative to compound 3 (Table 1, compounds 4–11). These differences were likely the result of the polar aniline and amine functional groups that were introduced into the chimeric degrader structures to facilitate antibody attachment. Such additions worsened the ability of the new degrader molecules to form long-lived BRD4/VHL-derived ternary complexes compared to 3 (4, 5, and 9–11) and/or impaired their cell permeability (4, 6, and 11). To conclude this phase of our research, we wished to also examine at least one chimeric BRD4 degrader that was more potent than 3 in the cell-based assays. Accordingly, we identified compound 12, which replaced the PEG spacer group present in 3 with a more-rigid bis-alkyne moiety (Figure 9, related chimeric BRD4 degraders are also known in the patent literature(43)). In our SPR assessments, degrader 12 formed a ternary complex with BRD4 and VHL that was somewhat longer-lived relative to the complex formed by 3 (Table 1). Consistent with ternary complex stability influencing biological activity, degrader 12 was also 2–3-fold more potent than 3 in cell-based assessments of MYC suppression, BRD4 degradation, and antiproliferation (Table 1). Disappointingly, a STEAP1-targeting conjugate prepared from 12 using the same methylene alkoxy carbamate linker employed to construct the STEAP1–3a-D6 ADC described above exhibited weaker and less-extensive BRD4 degradation effects relative to the previously studied conjugate (STEAP1–12a, Table 2). ADCs derived from 12 and carbonate-based disulfide linkers were somewhat more potent in the PC3-S1 BRD4 degradation assessments relative to the corresponding conjugates prepared from degrader 3 (Table 2, respectively, compare STEAP1–12b, STEAP1–12c, and STEAP1–12d with STEAP1–3b, STEAP1–3c, and STEAP1–3d). However, as was noted for the ADCs related to degrader 3, the BRD4 degradation activities observed for the disulfide-containing STEAP1 conjugates derived from 12 were not well-separated from the results obtained for the corresponding CLL1 controls and may reflect partial cleavage of the disulfide linkers in the cell culture assay media.(40)
    Chimeric protein degraders are relatively complicated modalities in comparison to typical small-molecule therapeutics, and their development requires the precise balancing of multiple biological parameters (target and ligase binding affinities, the ability to form productive ternary complexes, cell permeabilities, etc.).(27) Antibody–drug conjugates are similarly complex entities, which also require addressing multiple parameters to afford meaningful in vitro and in vivo activities (target antigen, conjugation method, drug loading, linker-attachment and release mechanisms, etc.).(16) This work describes the combination of these two modalities to produce even more-complicated agents in which many independent parameters likely contribute to the observed biological outcomes. Since no prior descriptions of systematic development of such antibody–degrader conjugates existed, we performed extensive analysis of the data presented in Tables 1 and 2 in an effort to better understand the drivers of antibody-mediated in vitro BRD4 degradation. Through such analysis, we sought to (1) identify trends that could further improve the activities of the ADCs of the present study and (2) provide strategies for the development of additional chimeric degrader conjugates that target proteins other than BRD4.
    Figure 10 presents a graphical depiction of the BRD4 DC50 and Sinf values for the conjugates described in this work (cf., Table 2). The ADCs are grouped in the figure according to their linker release mechanisms and, in the case of protease-cleavable linkers, are further organized by the functional group employed for linker-attachment purposes. When the data are viewed in this manner, several important trends become apparent. First, and most importantly, nearly all of the STEAP1-targeting conjugates exhibited more potent BRD4 DC50 values relative to the corresponding CLL1 and HER2 control conjugates with meaningful separations noted between the different outcomes (i.e., purple dots in Figure 10 were almost always lower on the y-axis relative to blue and/or yellow dots for a given linker-drug). This trend clearly demonstrated the repeated and general antigen-dependent delivery of the chimeric degraders to the STEAP1-expressing PC3-S1 cells, which was a key objective of this research. In addition, no single linker release mechanism appeared to provide an optimal combination of BRD4 DC50 potency, extent of BRD4 degradation (Sinf), and wide separation from control ADCs. Within a particular release mechanism class, DC50 and Sinf outcomes often varied considerably and were likely influenced by other parameters such as the ability of the released degraders to form long-lived BRD4/VHL ternary complexes (cf., Figure 5 above and associated discussion). One clear trend in Figure 10 was that conjugates derived from glutathione (GSH)-cleavable disulfide linkers exhibited the most potent and most extensive BRD4 degradation properties (3b–d and 12b–d). However, as discussed above, these activities were narrowly separated from those associated with the corresponding control ADCs and may result from partial linker cleavage in the cell culture media under the assay conditions. Interestingly, although the majority of chimeric degraders 3–12 exhibited near-complete BRD4 degradation outcomes when tested in the unconjugated form (Table 1, Sinf > 95%; exceptions are 5 and 9), the same molecules often afforded significantly less-extensive degradation results when delivered via the STEAP1-targeting antibodies (some examples are 4a, 8a, 10a, and 12a). As a possible consequence, there was no obvious correlation between DC50 potency and the extent of BRD4 degradation (Sinf) for the tested conjugates (i.e., the purple dots in Figure 10 that were the lowest on the y-axis were not always the largest in size). Once again, the observed lack of correlation was likely due to the influence of many other parameters on these biological outcomes.
    Figure 11 depicts the Table 2 BRD4 DC50 and Sinf outcomes similar to Figure 10 but instead groups the linker-drugs to enable easy comparison of cleavable and noncleavable linkers (only ADCs for which both linker versions were prepared and tested are included). Conjugates derived from the noncleavable linkers were always less potent than the corresponding cleavable entities (sometimes considerably so) but occasionally exhibited somewhat more extensive BRD4 degradation Sinf properties (compare 5a with 5b, 6a with 6b, 7a with 7b, 9a with 9b, and 10a with 10b). As discussed above and as depicted in Scheme S6, ADCs derived from noncleavable linkers are expected to produce highly polar intracellular catabolites that are unlikely to enter neighboring cells not targeted by the conjugate. This lack of “bystander” effects may have contributed to the weaker DC50 values noted above for the ADCs bearing noncleavable linkers and was consistent with the inactivity of the STEAP1–11a conjugate, which released a polar cell-impermeable degrader (Table 2 and Figure 8). As the noncleavable linkers appeared to offer no obvious advantages relative to cleavable options, we chose to deprioritize the use of the former entities in our future BRD4 degrader conjugate development efforts.
    As mentioned several times throughout this work, none of the STEAP1-targeting BRD4 degrader conjugates were active in antiproliferation assessments conducted in PC3-S1 cells (Table 2). In contrast, the corresponding unconjugated chimeric degraders 3–12 exhibited measurable antiproliferation activities when tested against the same cell line (Table 1). However, the cell-killing potencies of these molecules were significantly weaker than those associated with successful cytotoxic ADC payloads, which often resided in the low-nanomolar to picomolar range.(16) Accordingly, we suspected that conjugation of more-potent degraders with improved BRD4 DC50 values and/or antiproliferation properties relative to 3–12 would be required to produce STEAP1-targeting ADCs with the desired cell-killing activities.
    A plot of unconjugated chimeric degrader BRD4 degradation potency versus conjugate DC50 values revealed a loose trend that suggested that improvements in the former parameter could also improve the latter (Figure 12). This pattern was apparent even if the conjugates derived from GSH-cleavable linkers, whose activities may be influenced by cell-media linker cleavage, were removed from the analysis. Many of the outliers to the general trend were associated with ADCs bearing noncleavable linkers (e.g., 5b, 9b, and 10b) and, as described above, such entities were not envisioned to be incorporated into our future development plans. The disparate performance of conjugates STEAP1–5a and STEAP1–5b relative to unconjugated degrader 5 was notable with the former two entities exhibiting much more active BRD4 degradation properties in PC3-S1 cells relative to the latter molecule. These outcomes suggested that additional (non-VHL-based) BRD4 degradation mechanisms might be associated with the propargyl amine moiety present in 5 and that these properties were somehow enhanced via antibody-mediated delivery. However, additional studies are required to fully understand the observed phenomenon.
    To further support the conclusion that conjugation of more potent chimeric BRD4 degraders would be required to achieve STEAP1 ADCs with PC3-S1 cell-killing properties, we compared the intracellular concentrations of compound 8 that resulted from various forms of antibody-mediated delivery to those associated with non-antibody-mediated transport of the unconjugated molecule. As shown in Figure 13, exposure of PC3-S1 cells to media containing unconjugated 8 afforded high intracellular compound concentrations that were similar when measured at 4 and 22 h. These observations were consistent with rapid diffusion of the molecule across the cell membranes, but we did not investigate whether such diffusion was passive or transporter-mediated in nature. The depicted intracellular concentrations were also not corrected for compound binding to intracellular proteins or other entities in that environment, and the measured values do not inform regarding the compound 8 levels in any subcellular compartment (e.g., nucleus, lysosome, cytosol, etc.). The intracellular-to-extracellular concentration ratios observed for 8 were consistent with those reported previously by others for a panel of structurally unrelated neutral molecules.(53) In contrast, the ratios for 8 were somewhat lower compared to those determined by us for the well-known cytotoxic ADC payload monomethyl auristatin E (MMAE, which contains a basic amine) using a quantitation method similar to that described in this work (Figure S12). Importantly, the caveats mentioned above associated with the described intracellular quantitation methodology should be considered throughout the subsequent discussion regarding antibody-mediated delivery of compound 8.
    The data shown in Figure 13 suggested that extracellular concentrations of 8, which corresponded to the compound’s measured BRD4 DC50 value (85 nM, Table 1), resulted in intracellular concentrations of roughly 10 000 nM at either time point. As also depicted in Figure 13, the intracellular levels of 8 observed 4 and 22 h after treatment of PC3-S1 cells with the DAR2 STEAP1–8a-D2 conjugate at all tested concentrations were much lower than this 10 000 nM threshold. These levels were consistent with our related intracellular quantitation of MMAE following antibody-mediated delivery to WSU-DLCL2 cells.(54) The results also helped explain the inability of STEAP1–8a-D2 to afford measurable PC3-S1 BRD4 degradation activity even when examined at high concentrations (cf., Table 2). In contrast, and consistent with its higher payload loading, the DAR6 STEAP1–8a-D6 ADC afforded higher intracellular PC3-S1 levels of 8 relative to STEAP1–8a-D2, which increased significantly between the 4 and 22 h time points. Since we did not assess compound 8 intracellular concentrations beyond 22 h, it remains unknown whether the levels associated with STEAP1–8a-D6 exceeded the 10 000 nM threshold mentioned above after longer time periods. As the extent of BRD4 degradation displayed by STEAP1–8a-D6 in the PC3-S1 cells was attenuated relative to the unconjugated compound (43 versus 98%; Tables 2 and 1, respectively), we suspected that such levels may not have reached the 10 000 nM value or may have done so only near the end of the 72 h assay window employed for the STEAP1-conjugate BRD4 degradation assessments. The origins of the nonlinear increases in compound 8 intracellular concentrations afforded by the STEAP1–8a-D6 conjugate relative to STEAP1–8a-D2 (particularly at the 22 h time point) are currently not known but may involve differences in ADC trafficking, payload release efficiencies, and/or STEAP1 antigen recycling properties. Reassuringly, and consistent with STEAP1 antigen-mediated delivery of the chimeric degrader payloads, CLL1-targeted ADCs corresponding to STEAP1–8a-D2 and STEAP1–8a-D6 afforded lower intracellular concentrations of compound 8 in related quantitation experiments (Figure 13, dashed lines).
    Further analysis of the Figure 13 data for unconjugated compound 8 indicated that intracellular concentrations in excess of 50 000 nM were associated with the compound’s extracellular PC3-S1 antiproliferation IC50 parameter (1300 nM, Table 1). Based on the results shown in Figure 13, the intracellular levels of 8 corresponding to STEAP1–8a-D6 did not reach these lofty values after 22 h and likely never did even following multiday exposures. As with the BRD4 degradation outcomes discussed above, the collective data helped explain why even the DAR6 STEAP1–8a-D6 conjugate was unable to demonstrate PC3-S1 antiproliferation effects when tested to high concentrations. This observation also supported the strategy of conjugating more potent BRD4 degraders to the STEAP1-targeting antibodies as one means of achieving the desired antiproliferation outcomes. Assuming that the intracellular concentrations associated with unconjugated compound 8 were representative of most chimeric BRD4 degraders, a more potent antiproliferation IC50 value (i.e., a leftward shift on the x-axis of Figure 13) would translate to lower intracellular concentrations that might better approximate those achievable via delivery by a DAR6 ADC. Alternate approaches involving higher DAR loadings and/or increased intracellular unbound degrader concentrations were also considered but not pursued during this portion of our studies. The search for chimeric BRD4 degraders with improved antiproliferation properties relative to 8 (or any other degrader described in this work) therefore became a central focus of the next phase of our research activities.
    As one means of testing this hypothesis, we examined the antiproliferation activity of the STEAP1–8a-D6 conjugate using the LNCaP prostate cancer line. In the unconjugated form, compound 8 displayed more potent antiproliferation effects against the LNCaP line relative to its potency toward PC3-S1 cells (250 versus 1300 nM, Tables 1 and S3). The LNCaP cells also expressed significantly higher levels of the STEAP1 antigen as compared to the PC3-S1 line (Figure S1a). Encouragingly, the STEAP1–8a-D6 conjugate exhibited measurable antiproliferation activity when tested using LNCaP cells that was clearly separated from effects associated with the corresponding CLL1–8a-D6 control ADC (Figure 14). It is currently unknown if these outcomes resulted from the stronger antiproliferation potency of unconjugated 8 toward LNCaP cells relative to the PC3-S1 line, the higher STEAP1 antigen expression in the former cells compared to the latter, or a combination of both differences. In addition, western blot analysis demonstrated the ability of STEAP1–8a-D6 (but not a related HER2–8a-D6 control ADC) to degrade BRD4 in a dose-dependent manner at concentrations that approximated the conjugate’s antiproliferation IC50 value (Figure S13). Unfortunately, STEAP1–8a-D6 was the only ADC described in this work to display meaningful LNCaP antiproliferation activity (Table S3). Thus, although promising, these initial LNCaP antiproliferation outcomes illustrated the need for further development of the chimeric BRD4 degrader compounds and the related antibody-conjugates under study.
    To complete this phase of our research, we examined the in vivo stability and pharmacokinetic properties of selected ADCs that were prepared during the studies described above. Although these conjugates were not sufficiently potent to warrant their evaluation in efficacy experiments, we wished to confirm that (1) the employed linkers remained connected to the antibodies during circulation in vivo and (2) attachment of multiple chimeric degrader payloads to the mAb surfaces did not negatively alter the expected pharmacokinetic profiles. As shown in Figure 15, the CLL1–8a-D6 and CLL1–12d ADCs displayed good stability properties over the course of several days following IV administration of each conjugate to mice. Analysis of the corresponding mass spectrometry data indicated that CLL1–8a-D6 DAR loss was associated with biotransformation of one of the attached chimeric degrader molecules (amide cleavage; Figure S14a,b). Encouragingly, minimal loss of the attached linker-drugs via retro-Michael reactions was observed during the course of the multiday experiment (Figure 15). Similarly, the CLL1–12d ADC also exhibited good in vivo stability properties with the majority of its DAR changes related to carbonate cleavages noted for the LC-K149 and/or HC-L174 mAb attachment sites (Figures 15 and S15a,b). Our prior studies demonstrated that in vivo ADC stability outcomes were independent of the administered dose and the target antigen.(30,36) Accordingly, the described results provided confidence that STEAP1-targeting conjugates derived from maleimide and disulfide-containing linker-drugs related to 8a and 12d would also afford favorable in vivo stability properties.
    Figure 16 depicts the total antibody pharmacokinetic profile of ADC CLL1–8a-D6 as determined using a liquid chromatography with tandem mass spectrometry (LCMS/MS)-based assessment following a single IV administration to mice. Over the course of the 7 day study, the in vivo behavior of the conjugate appeared to be similar to that observed for the corresponding unconjugated CLL1 antibody whose mouse pharmacokinetic profile was determined in a separate experiment.(55) The outcomes noted for CLL1–8a-D6, coupled with the conjugate’s favorable stability profile mentioned above, encouragingly indicated that the ADC’s pharmacokinetic profile was not dramatically changed relative to that associated with the unconjugated mAb, which lacked the attached chimeric degrader payloads. However, since the sampling in the CLL1–8a-D6 experiment was sparse and fairly limited, pharmacokinetic studies involving additional data points and/or longer durations are required to fully compare the conjugate with its CLL1 mAb counterpart. Related profiling of alternate ADCs bearing chimeric degrader payloads and linkers that differ from those present in 8a is also required to determine whether attachment of those linker-drugs negatively impacts antibody pharmacokinetics. In spite of these caveats, the encouraging in vivo profiles of CLL1–8a-D6 and CLL1–12d further motivated us to continue our exploration of the chimeric BRD4 degrader conjugates.
    The unconjugated chimeric degraders described in this work and the corresponding linker-drugs required for ADC syntheses were generated by a variety of methods that are depicted in the following schemes. The preparation of linker-drugs 3a–d is shown in Schemes 1 and 2. Deprotection of the tert-butyl ester present in compound 1(3) under acidic conditions afforded acid 13 (Scheme 1). This crude material was converted to the corresponding N-hydroxysuccinimide ester and then coupled to amine 15 (HCl salt; prepared in one step from commercially available 14) to give intermediate 16. As depicted in Scheme 2, the known Boc-protected VHL-binding moiety 17(56) was derivatized with bromoacetic acid to give intermediate 18. Removal of the Boc group from 18 followed by hexafluorophosphate azabenzotriazole tetramethyl uronium (HATU)-mediated coupling of the resulting amine salt (not shown) with intermediate 16 provided the chimeric intermediate 19 after prep-high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) purification. Transformation of 19 to linker-drug 3a was then accomplished by sequential treatment with diphenylphosphoryl azide (DPPA) (to generate the corresponding acyl azide, not shown) and subsequent tin-catalyzed coupling with benzyl alcohol 20.(57) Preparation of linker-drugs 3b–d was achieved by, respectively, coupling alcohols 21, 22, and 23 with 17 to give the corresponding carbonates 24, 25, and 26 (Scheme 2). Alcohols 21 and 22 were synthesized from the known 5-nitro-2-pyridine-disulfide analogs(58) in one step as described in the Experimental Section, while alcohol 23 was prepared from commercial starting materials. Deprotection of intermediates 24 and 25 under acidic conditions and coupling of the resulting amine salts with carboxylic acid 16, respectively, afforded linker-drugs 3b and 3c. In contrast, compound 3d was synthesized from 26 via iterative deprotection/coupling cycles involving carboxylic acids 14 and 13, which proceeded through intermediate 27.
    The preparation of chimeric degrader 4 and the related linker-drugs 4a and 4b is depicted in Scheme 3. Compound 1 was converted into aniline 28 in good yield using a two-step procedure. Protection of the aniline moiety present in 28 as the corresponding 2,2,2-trifluoroacetamide (29) followed by acidic deprotection of the tert-butyl ester then afforded carboxylic acid 30. This material was subjected to HATU-mediated coupling with amine 31(59) and subsequent aniline deprotection via mild basic hydrolysis to give chimeric degrader 4. Conversion of 4 to linker-drug 4a was accomplished by derivatization of the aniline present in the former compound with fluorenylmethoxycarbonyl (Fmoc)-protected l-citrulline to provide intermediate 32 followed by Fmoc deprotection and coupling of the resulting amine (not shown) with carboxylic acid 33(60) (Scheme 3). Alternatively, compound 28 was converted to the corresponding isocyanate (not shown) by treatment with triphosgene, and this new entity was condensed with alcohol 20(57) to give intermediate 34. Removal of the tert-butyl ester present in 34 under acidic conditions and HATU-mediated coupling of the resulting carboxylic acid (35) with amine 31(59) subsequently afforded linker-drug 4b (Scheme 3).
    The synthesis of chimeric degrader 5 and linker-drugs 5a and 5b is shown in Scheme 4. Palladium-mediated coupling of compound 1 with propargyl amine under microwave conditions provided intermediate 36. Fmoc-protection of the amine moiety of 36 (to give 37) followed by acidic cleavage of the tert-butyl ester then afforded carboxylic acid 38. Coupling of 38 with amine 31(59) was accomplished using HATU, and the Fmoc group present in the resulting product (not shown) was deprotected under mild basic conditions to give compound 5. Alternatively, coupling of 36 with Fmoc-protected l-citrulline provided intermediate 39. This entity was deprotected under basic conditions, and the resulting amine (not shown) was coupled with carboxylic acid 33(60) to give 40 (Scheme 4). Removal of the tert-butyl group present in 40 followed by coupling of the resulting carboxylic acid (41) with amine 31(59) gave linker-drug 5a. Linker-drug 5b was prepared by derivatization of 36 with commercially available 42 to provide intermediate 43 followed by acidic tert-butyl deprotection and HATU-mediated coupling of the resulting carboxylic acid (44) with amine 31(59) (Scheme 4).
    Chimeric degrader 6 and linker-drugs 6a and 6b were prepared using the methods depicted in Scheme 5. The known benzyl amine fragment 45(51c,61) was protected as the corresponding Boc derivative (46), and this entity was coupled with commercially available benzyl N-(2-hydroxyethyl)-N-methyl-carbamate (not shown) under Mitsunobu conditions at elevated temperature to give intermediate 47. Removal of the Boc group present in 47 followed by coupling of the resulting amine (HCl salt, 48) with the known dipeptide fragment 49(56a) then gave intermediate 50. This compound was subjected to iterative Boc deprotection and HATU-mediated coupling cycles involving carboxylic acids 14 and 13 to provide intermediate 52 (via Boc-protected 51). Removal of the benzyloxycarbonyl (Cbz) protecting group present in 52 by treatment with iodotrimethylsilane (TMSI) then afforded chimeric degrader 6. This entity was transformed into linker-drug 6a by coupling with the mixed carbonate 53(57) under mild basic conditions (Scheme 5). Derivatization of 6 with commercially available compound 42 alternatively generated linker-drug 6b following prep-HPLC purification (Scheme 5).
    Scheme 6 depicts the preparation of chimeric degrader 7 and the related linker-drugs 7a and 7b. The phenol present in the known compound 54(61,62) was coupled to ortho-nitro-phenylsulfonate 55 (prepared in one step from Cbz-protected 4-hydroxy-piperidine) to give intermediate 56. Deprotection of the Boc group contained in 56 followed by coupling of the resulting amine 57 (TFA salt) with carboxylic acid 14 afforded intermediate 58. Removal of the Boc group from this compound and coupling of the amine thus produced (TFA salt, not shown) with carboxylic acid 13 gave the chimeric product 59. The Cbz protecting group present in 59 was then cleaved by treatment with TMSI to provide degrader 7. This material was independently coupled with mixed carbonate 53(57) or commercially available compound 42 to, respectively, give linker-drugs 7a and 7b (Scheme 6).
    The syntheses of chimeric degrader 8 and the corresponding linker-drug 8a are shown in Scheme 7. Dibenzyl-protected alcohol 60(63) was coupled with tert-butyl 2-bromoacetate to give ester 61. The benzyl groups present in this intermediate were removed via hydrogenation, and the diphenol compound thus obtained (62) was monoalkylated with Cbz-protected 2-bromoethylamine in moderate yield to afford 63. The phenol moiety contained in 63 was then transformed into the corresponding Boc-protected aniline (compound 65) via sequential conversion to the trifluoromethylsulfonate (64) and Pd-catalyzed coupling of this entity with tert-butyl carbamate. Cleavage of the Cbz group contained in 65 afforded the deprotected amine (not shown), and this intermediate was subjected to HATU-mediated coupling with carboxylic acid 13 to give compound 66. Simultaneous removal of the Boc and tert-butyl protecting groups under acidic conditions afforded aniline-acid 67, and this entity was coupled to the known amine 68(56a) to give the chimeric degrader 8. Derivatization of the aniline present in 8 by sequential transformation to the corresponding isocyanate (not shown) and treatment with alcohol 20(57) then provided linker-drug 8a following prep-HPLC purification.
    Chimeric degrader 9 and the related linker-drugs 9a and 9b were prepared by the methods shown in Scheme 8. Commercially available compound 69 was hydrogenated in the presence of PtO2 to give the cis-diester 70. Boc protection of this intermediate (to give 71) followed by reduction with diisobutylaluminium hydride (DIBAL-H) then afforded the mixture of cis-piperidine isomers. The alcohol present in 73 was derivatized with Cbz-protected aziridine 74(64) to give the racemic intermediate 75 and the C diol 72. This material was monoalkylated with ethyl 2-diazoacetate under rhodium-catalyzed conditions to provide ester-alcohol 73 in moderate yield as a racembz group contained therein was subsequently removed via hydrogenation. The resulting racemic amine (76) was coupled with carboxylic acid 13 via a HATU-mediated protocol, and the ester-containing intermediate thus obtained (77, 1:1 mix of diastereomers) was hydrolyzed under mild basic conditions to afford carboxylic acid 78 (1:1 mix of diastereomers). Coupling of this entity with the known amine 68(56a) then gave the chimeric intermediate 79, and the Boc group contained in this material was removed under acidic conditions to give degrader 9 (1:1 mixture of diastereomers) as a HCl salt. Coupling of 9 with the mixed carbonate 53(57) or with commercially available compound 42, respectively, provided linker-drugs 9a and 9b (Scheme 8).
    Scheme 9 depicts the synthesis of chimeric degrader compound 10 and the related linker-drugs 10a and 10b. Carboxylic acid 13 was transformed into the thiazole-containing compound 82 by a three-step process involving (1) conversion to the corresponding primary amide (80), (2) treatment with Lawesson’s reagent to generate intermediate 81, and (3) condensation with 2-bromo-1,1-diethoxyethane under acidic conditions. The central portion of 10 and related compounds was constructed by converting commercially available carboxylic acid 83 to alcohol 84 via reduction with borane. Alkylation of 84 with tert-butyl 2-bromoacetate using phase-transfer methods afforded ester 85, which was subsequently converted to carboxylic acid 86 by treatment with TFA. Reduction of the acid group present in 86 with the borane dimethyl sulfide complex provided alcohol 87, which was then protected as the corresponding tert-butyldimethylsilyl (TBS) ether to give 88. Palladium-catalyzed coupling of one bromide group present in 88 with tert-butyl acrylate afforded intermediate 89, and the remaining bromide moiety present in this entity was converted to Boc-protected aniline 90 via a second Pd-catalyzed transformation. Hydrogenation of 90 at elevated temperature reduced the olefin contained in the molecule and simultaneously cleaved the TBS ether to provide alcohol 91. This intermediate was alkylated with propargyl bromide to give 92, and this new entity was coupled with the thiazole-containing compound 82 (prepared above) using a palladium-catalyzed method under microwave conditions to provide 93. Simultaneous cleavage of the Boc and tert-butyl groups present in 93 via treatment with TFA afforded carboxylic acid 94, and this material was subjected to HATU-mediated coupling with amine 68(56a) to provide chimeric degrader 10. Conversion of 10 to linker-drug 10a was accomplished by treatment with mixed carbonate 53(57) under a mild basic condition (Scheme 9). Similarly, coupling of 10 with commercially available 42 generated linker-drug 10b (Scheme 9).
    The methods employed to prepare chimeric degrader 11 and the linker-drug 11a are shown in Scheme 10. Palladium-catalyzed coupling of alkyne intermediate 92 with the known BRD4-binding molecule 95(65) under microwave conditions provided compound 96. The Boc and tert-butyl groups present in this entity were simultaneously removed by treatment with TFA, and the aniline contained in the resulting intermediate (97) was then reprotected as the corresponding Boc derivative (98). HATU-mediated coupling of 98 with the known amine 68(56a) subsequently provided the chimeric molecule 99. The methyl ester present in 99 was hydrolyzed under mild basic conditions, and the resulting carboxylic acid (100) was coupled with 2-aminoethanesulfonic acid to afford intermediate 101. Removal of the Boc group contained in this entity was accomplished by treatment with TFA to give chimeric degrader 11. Subsequent derivatization of the aniline present in 11 with the mixed carbonate 53(57) provided linker-drug 11a (Scheme 10).
    Scheme 11 illustrates the methods used to prepare chimeric degrader 12 and the related linker-drugs 12a–d. Commercially available diol 102 was monoalkylated with tert-butyl 2-bromoacetate to give intermediate 103. This entity was transformed into amine 105 via conversion to the corresponding phthalimide derivative 104 and subsequent exposure to hydrazine hydrate at elevated temperature. Coupling of amine 105 with carboxylic acid 13 then provided intermediate 106, and the tert-butyl group contained therein was subsequently cleaved under acidic conditions to afford carboxylic acid 107. This material was subjected to HATU-mediated coupling with amine 68(56a) to give chimeric degrader 12. Derivatization of the secondary hydroxyl group present in 12 with bromoacetic acid afforded intermediate 108. This entity was then transformed into linker-drug 12a via conversion to the corresponding acyl azide (109) and subsequent tin-catalyzed coupling with benzyl alcohol 20 (Scheme 2). Alternatively, carboxylic acid 107 was coupled with the amine salts obtained by acidic deprotection of intermediates 24, 25, and 26 (Scheme 2) to, respectively, provide linker-drugs 12b, 12c, and 12d.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    This work describes the first detailed account of the systematic exploration of antibody–drug conjugates that incorporate chimeric degrader payloads.
